Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Material Symbolism and Ochre Use in Middle Stone Age East-Central Africa

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Symbolism, including language, is widely viewed as an essential element of modern human behavior. Documenting the evolutionary origins of such behavior, however, has proven difficult. Ochre pigments (iron oxides) form a major part of the evidence used to interpret when humans began communicating through symbols. Excavations at Olorgesailie, Kenya; Karonga, Malawi; and Twin Rivers, Zambia have yielded ochre artifacts that may indicate very early occurrences of symbolism. Yet mineral pigments may also form naturally in archaeological sites, or may have technological rather than symbolic uses. This project will evaluate and further develop analytical approaches to the chemical "fingerprinting" of ochre artifacts and sources from these three African localities. Using Laser Ablation-Inductively Coupled Plasma-Mass Spectrometry and Instrumental Neutron Activation Analysis to facilitate the matching of artifacts to source deposits, the doctoral student Andrew Zipkin (George Washington University), under the supervision of Dr. Alison Brooks, will demonstrate the extent to which human ancestors were willing to seek out and transport specific pigments. This project also will use color quantifying technologies to determine if Middle Stone Age humans exhibited color preferences in the ochres that they collected and modified. Color preference potentially suggests symbolic use of ochre since the meaning given to different colors, such as in national flags, is a well-known aspect of modern human behavior.

The dissertation's final aspect will be an experimental evaluation of proposed non-symbolic uses of ochre. The leading alternative explanation is that ochre was an ingredient in plant resin adhesives used to construct compound tools, like stone-tipped spears. In collaboration with material scientists, the investigators will measure the effectiveness of different ochre minerals in formulating adhesives to test if glue production rather than symbolic meaning could explain past ochre procurement choices.

The research will contribute to the development of international collaborations between American, Australian, Canadian, Malawian, and Zambian researchers, as well as outreach activities for the general public. The development of new analytical approaches for "fingerprinting" mineral sources will find broad application in usage not just by archaeologists, but also by art historians, state agencies investigating the illegal transport of stolen antiquities, and forensic scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ochre is a broad term for a range of iron-containing rocks and minerals (similar to rust) that have been widely used as red and yellow pigments by humans from prehistory through present day.  Ochre artifacts and residues have been discovered in multiple African stone age archaeological sites dating to as old as 400,000 years ago and have been tentatively interpreted as evidence for symbolic behaviors like painting rock art and decorating the human body.  However, determining whether ochre artifacts constitute definite evidence of modern symbolic behaviors has proved challenging because there are many non-symbolic uses for ochre such as tanning animal hides, making adhesives, and protecting the skin from sunburn.  This project sought to improve and apply methods from geology, chemistry, and materials science to the study of ochre artifacts in order to help archaeologists interpret the significance of this type of material for the development of modern human behavior. Geochemical analyses developed during this project may also prove helpful in identifying fraudulent or stolen antiquities.

            During this project we identified natural sources of ochre rocks and minerals on the landscape near three archaeological sites that contained ochre artifacts.  The three sites, Chaminade 1A, Malawi, Olorgesailie, Kenya, and Twin Rivers Hill, Zambia, all have yielded pieces of ochre showing evidence of use or modification by humans.  A major goal of this project was to identify where the ochre for these artifacts was collected on the landscape and whether the people who collected them had preferences for particular sources.  The precise concentrations of various elements in ochre from a particular source are unique and can be used as a geochemical ‘fingerprint’ to match ochre artifacts from an archaeological site to their source on the landscape.  During this project we collaborated with scientists from the US, Canada, Norway, Kenya, and Malawi to refine the techniques used to measure elements in rocks and build databases of ochre source locations and their elemental fingerprints for central Kenya, northern Malawi, and central Zambia.  These databases will be freely available online through The Digital Archaeological Record for use by scientists anywhere in the world.
